{{Cleanup-biography|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Vladimir Ivanovich Lysenko | honorific_suffix = | image = NF-40(Vladimir Lysenko).jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = Vladimir Lysenko | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1955|01|01}} | birth_place = [[Kharkov]], [[USSR]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = Russian{{cn|date=June 2015}} | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Scientist | years_active = 1990–present | employer = Institute of Mechanics, [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] | organization = | agent = | known_for = World [[travel]] | notable_works = Stability and Transition of High-Speed Boundary Layers and Wakes | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = President, Union of Russian Around-the-World Travellers
Doctor of Philosophy, Fluid Mechanics | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = Himalayan Club of Russian Rafters & Kayakers (Chairman) | religion = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Vladimir Ivanovich Lysenko''' (Russian: Владимир Лысенко; born 1 January 1955) is a [[Russians|Russian]] academic and world traveller. He set several [[Guinness World Records]] related to high-altitude river rafting. ==Biography== Lysenko was born in [[Kharkov]], [[USSR]] on 1 January 1955. He had graduated from the [[National Aerospace University – Kharkiv Aviation Institute|Kharkov Aviation University]] (aircraft construction faculty) with honors and the postgraduate course of the Siberian Branch of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] (in the specialty "mechanics of fluid, gas and plasma"). ==Education== Lysenko holds a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Doctorate of Philosophy]] (Ph.D.) in [[fluid mechanics]]. He is a leading fellow at the Institute of Mechanics of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] in [[Novosibirsk]].{{cite web | url = http://exparty.ru/news.html?id=510&Page=5&month=&year=&day= | title = Двое новосибирцев отправились в уникальное путешествие |trans-title=Two Novosibirsk went to a unique journey | work = www.exparty.ru | date = 2004-09-20 | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.autoreview.ru/news/news247/page6.htm | script-title=ru:От Аляски до Огненной Земли |trans-title=From Alaska to Tierra del Fuego | author = ITAR-TASS | accessdate = 2011-01-29 | language = Russian }} He authored the book ''Stability and Transition of High-Speed Boundary Layers and Wakes'', as well as over 200 scientific papers. ==Traveling== ===Rafting=== [[File:Indonesia (New Guinea Island, on Kemabu River)(04).jpg|thumb|left|250px|Vladimir on Kemabu River, New Guinea]] Between 1991 and 1992, Lysenko became the first man to raft on rivers flowing down all of the world's [[eight-thousander]]s—the 14 mountains with peaks higher than {{convert|8000|m|ft|sp=us}} above sea level.{{cite web | url = http://www.shangri-la-river-expeditions.com/journals/lysenko/lysenkojournal.html | title = Rafting Down the Highest World Peaks | last = Lysenko | first = Vladimir | work = Exploring the Rivers of Western China | publisher = Earth Science Expeditions | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }}{{cite web | url = http://a-nomalia.narod.ru/divo/31-22.htm | script-title=ru:С "ГОРКИ" - НА КАТАМАРАНЕ |trans-title=On "Hills" - on a catamaran | work = «ДИВО» русская книга рекордов и достижений | language = Russian | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }} In 1996, Lysenko became the first man to raft down the highest peak of every continent (except the Antarctic), as well as the highest peak of [[Oceania]]. While rafting down Mount Everest in Nepal in April and May 1991, Lysenko set the Guinness World Record for the greatest altitude difference travelled in a rafting trip: a descent of {{convert|4500|m|ft|sp=us}} from Dughla on the Khumbu Glacier ({{convert|4600|m|ft|disp=or}} above sea level) to Chatara ({{convert|100|m|ft|disp=or}} above sea level). In September 1996, he set the Guinness World Record for high-altitude rafting with a {{convert|5600|m|ft|sp=us}} start on the Eastern Rong Chu River on Mount Everest;{{cite web | url = http://www.shangri-la-river-expeditions.com/1stdes/phung/rong.html | title = E. Rong Chu, Rong Chu and Phung Chu, Tibet, 1996 | work = Exploring the Rivers of Western China | publisher = Earth Science Expeditions | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }} the previous record of {{convert|5334|m|ft|sp=us}} had been set in September 1976 by the Mike-Jones team of [[England]]. Vladimir rafted also on mountain sources of [[Amazon River]] and the [[Nile]], kayaked on [[Yukon River]]. He rafted in 63 countries (including Nepal, China, Pakistan, India, Afghanistan, etc.).{{cite web | url = http://www.8000rivers.web-online.ru/ | title = The list of rafting expeditions of Vladimir Lysenko | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }} [[File:Lysenko-21 (Ulan Bator; Mongolia).jpg|thumb|250px|Vladimir Lysenko in Ulan Bator; Mongolia]] ===Circumnavigation in a car=== Between September 1997 and 2002, Lysenko crossed 62 countries by car. He crossed each continent (other than Antarctica) twice, traveling between the most distant points of each continent in both latitude and longitude. He crossed the Americas from [[Prudhoe Bay, Alaska]] to [[Tierra del Fuego]] in [[Argentina]]; from [[Punta Pariñas]], [[Peru]] to Cape Cabo Branko, [[Brazil]]; and from Anchor Bay, [[Alaska]] to [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]], [[Canada]]. His routes across Africa took him from [[Cape Agulhas]], [[South Africa]] to Ras-Angela Cape, [[Tunisia]]; and from [[Somali people|Somali]] to [[Dakar]]. Crossing Europe and Asia, he travelled from [[Cabo da Roca]], [[Portugal]] to Galimiy and [[Magadan]] in Russia; and from [[Tanjung Piai]] in [[Peninsular Malaysia]] to [[North Cape, Norway]]. Australia was crossed from [[Cape Byron]] to [[Steep Point]] and from [[Cape York Peninsula]] to [[South Point (Wilsons Promontory)|South Point]]. These travels totaled {{convert|160000|km|mi|sp=us}}.{{cite web | url = http://www.vvv.ru/papers/lisenko/lisenko.php3 | script-title=ru:Биография Владимира Лысенко | language = Russian |trans-title=Biography of Vladimir Lysenko | last = Lysenko | first = Vladimir | publisher = Vinchi Group | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }}{{cite web | url = http://veter.turizm.ru/40/pervaya.shtml | script-title=ru:Первая российская автомобильная кругосветка |trans-title=The first Russian automobile circumnavigation | last = Lysenko | first = Vladimir | work = BB | accessdate = 2011-01-29 | language = Russian }}{{cite web | url = http://veter.turizm.ru/42/lysenko.shtml | script-title=ru:Владимир Лысенко никак не уймется. |trans-title=Vladimir Lysenko, not her kill. |date=January 2000 | work = BB | number = 42 | accessdate = 2011-01-29 | language = Russian }}{{cite web | url = http://equator.rosbalt.ru/art_list_86.html | script-title=ru:Владимир Лысенко |trans-title=Vladimir Lysenko | language = Russian | work = Rusia | publisher = Торгово-Промышленной группой «Сибтранс» | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }} For the trip departing from Anchorage, the limited finances of Lysenko's team lead them to buy a used [[Volvo 200 Series|Volvo 240]] with {{convert|300000|mi|km}} on the odometer for {{currency|2500}}.{{cite interview | url = http://www.vokrugsveta.ru/vs/article/777/ | script-title=ru:Через две Америки на автомобиле |trans-title=Two of America by car |date=July 1998 | accessdate = 2011-01-29 | last = Lysenko | first = Vladimir | interviewer = Andrew Shapran | work = Вокруг Света | language = Russian }} [[File:Lysenko-19 (Deidades Tutelares, Chile).jpg|thumb|left|250px|V.Lysenko in Deidades Tutelares, Chile]] ===Circumnavigation on a bicycle=== The start was in [[Vladivostok]], [[Russia]] in 2006. Lysenko has ridden {{convert|41800|km|mi|sp=us}} on a bicycle. He has cycled via 29 countries - Russia, Mongolia, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, Slovakia, Austria, Germany, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, Italy, France, Spain, Morocco (and Western Sahara), São Tomé and Príncipe, Argentina, Chile, Peru, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Belize, Mexico, the United States, Kiribati, Nauru, New Zealand, Australia, Indonesia, North Korea.{{cite news | url = http://primamedia.ru/news/show/?id=24722&viewmode=print | script-title=ru:Российский путешественник проехал на велосипеде от Владивостока до Белгорода |trans-title=Russian traveler rode a bicycle from Vladivostok to Belgorod | date = 2006-11-02 | agency = PrimaMedia | newspaper = PrimaMedia | accessdate = 2011-01-29 | language = Russian }}{{cite news | url = http://dvsport.info/show.php?p=&id=3467 | title = Russian Traveler Rides 6,300 Miles on Bicycle across Russia | date = 2006-11-02 | agency = PrimaMedia }} {{cite news | url = http://www.vvv.ru/news/index.php3?news=103661 | script-title=ru:Владимир Лысенко пересек на велосипеде Аргентину и Чили |trans-title=Vladimir Lysenko had crossed Argentina and Chile in a bicycle | date = 2009-12-01 | agency = Экстремальный портал VVV.RU | language = Russian }} {{cite news | url = http://www.vvv.ru/print_news.php?news=110439 | script-title=ru:Владимир Лысенко проехал на велосипеде от Сан-Сальвадора до Лос-Анджелеса |trans-title=Vladimir Lysenko had cycled from San Salvador to Los Angeles | date = 2010-03-04 | agency = Экстремальный портал VVV.RU | language = Russian }} {{cite news | url = http://www.vvv.ru/news/index.php3?news=120935 | script-title=ru:Известный путешественник Владимир Лысенко в мае 2010г. пересек на велосипеде Марокко |trans-title=The famous traveler Vladimir Lysenko had crossed Morocco in a bicycle in May of 2010 | date = 2010-06-10 | agency = Экстремальный портал VVV.RU | language = Russian }} {{cite news | url = http://ua-reporter.com/novosti/95831 | script-title=ru:По Западной Европе на велосипеде |trans-title=Via Western Europe in a bicycle | date = 2010-09-24 | agency = UA-Reporter.com | language = Russian }} {{cite news | url = http://www.vvv.ru/news/index.php3?news=156167 | script-title=ru:Владимир Лысенко в январе-феврале 2011г. проехал на велосипеде 5600 км по Австралии и Новой Зеландии |trans-title=Vladimir Lysenko had cycled 5,600 km in Australia and New Zealand in January–February of 2011 | date = 2011-03-14 | agency = Экстремальный портал VVV.RU | language = Russian }} ===The path of Gold Rush=== In 2003, Lysenko duplicated the path of the [[Klondike Gold Rush]] of 1897–1898, travelling by foot and kayak.{{cite web | url = http://www.outdoors.ru/news/2004/11/11_20.php | title = До путешествия по Южной Америке Владимир Лысенко прошел маршрутом героев "золотой лихорадки" |trans-title=Prior to traveling to South America, Vladimir Lysenko took the route of heroes gold rush | work = OutdoorsNEWS | date = 2004-11-11 | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }} [[File:NF-15(in yacht).jpg|thumb|250px|V.Lysenko in a yacht in Indian Ocean]] ===Circumnavigation along the equator=== Lysenko had circumnavigated the globe from west to east, straying no more than two degrees of latitude from the [[Equator]]. Starting in Libreville ([[Gabon]]), Vladimir had successfully crossed (in a [[car]], a [[motor boat]], a [[yacht]], a [[ship]], a [[kayak]], a [[bicycle]], and by [[foot]]) [[Africa]] (from Libreville ([[Gabon]]) to Kiunga ([[Kenya]]) through [[Gabon]], [[Republic of Congo]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Uganda]] and [[Kenya]]), [[Indian Ocean]], [[Indonesia]] (from Padang to Biak), [[Pacific Ocean]], [[South America]] (from Pedernales ([[Ecuador]]) to Macapa ([[Brazil]]) through [[Ecuador]], [[Colombia]] and [[Brazil]]) and [[Atlantic Ocean]] with finish in Libreville in 2012.{{cite web | url = http://www.tag.spb.ru/persons/lysenko/ekvator.html | script-title=ru:Кругосветка ВЛАДИМИРА ЛЫСЕНКО по экватору на автомобиле, яхте, на плоту и пешком |trans-title=Circumnavigation Vladimir Lysenko: along the equator in a car, boat, raft and on foot | work = Диагональный Мир | date = 2001 | publisher = группа TAG | language = Russian }}{{cite web | url = http://www.rosc.ru/sport/lysenko/krugosvetka.shtml | script-title=ru:КРУГОСВЕТКА НА ЯХТЕ ПО ЭКВАТОРУ |trans-title=Around the World on the Yacht at the equator | work = Russian Ocean Sailing Club | language = Russian | date = 2006 | accessdate = 2011-01-29 }} [[File:NF-08(in mine).jpg|thumb|left|250px|Lysenko at the depth of 3.5 km]] ===Project "From Earth's Bowels to Stratosphere"=== In his project titled "From Earth's bowels to [[stratosphere]]", Lysenko descended (in 2004) to the bottom of the world's deepest [[Mining|mine]], the Mponeng Gold Mine in [[Carletonville]], [[South Africa]], a depth of {{convert|3.4615|km|mi|sp=us}} below ground. Then he had traveled in a car from Carletonville to [[Moscow]], passing through South Africa, [[Namibia]], [[Angola]], the [[Republic of the Congo|Congo]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Zaire]], [[Kenya]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Sudan]], [[Egypt]], [[Jordan]], [[Syria]], [[Lebanon]], [[Turkey]], [[Azerbaijan]], and [[Russia]]. And then Lysenko made a series of lifting by various planes to the stratosphere (to the height of 11-16,5 km). Difference of altitudes on this route (from the mine bottom to the stratosphere) was 3.5 + 16.5 = {{convert|20|km|mi|sp=us}}, and difference of temperatures 58°+ |-56°| = 114°С. [[File:V.Lysenko's circumnavigations.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Routes of circumnavigations of Vladimir Lysenko]] ===Vladimir had visited all 195 countries (UN members and observers).=== ==Affiliations== Lysenko is the President of Union of Russian Around-the-World Travelers{{cite web | url = http://skr2.ru/ | title = Союз Кругосветчиков России |trans-title=Union Krugosvetchikov Russia | publisher = Union Krugosvetchikov Russia | accessdate = 2018-02-15 }}, and the Chairman of Himalayan Club of Russian Rafters & Kayakers{{cite web | url = http://gkrkr.ru// | title = Гималайский Клуб Рафтеров и Каякеров России |trans-title=Himalayan Club of Russian Rafters & Kayakers | publisher = Himalayan Club of Russian Rafters & Kayakers | accessdate = 2018-02-15 }}. ==Bibliography== * [http://skr2.ru/lysenko/lysenko-splav.php/ Vladimir Lysenko. Rafting Down the Highest World Peaks] {{Link language|ru}} 1997. Novosibirsk * [http://skr2.ru/lysenko/lysenko-avto.php/ Vladimir Lysenko. Round-the-World Tour In a Car] {{Link language|ru}} 2002. Novosibirsk * V.I.Lysenko. Stability and Transition of High-Speed Boundary Layers and Wakes. {{Link language|ru}} 2006. Novosibirsk * [http://skr2.ru/lysenko/lysenko-veloputishestvie.php/ Vladimir Lysenko. Round-the-World Tour On a Bicycle] {{Link language|ru}} 2014. Novosibirsk * [http://skr2.ru/lysenko/lysenko-ekvator.php/ Vladimir Lysenko.Round-the-World Tour Along the Equator] {{Link language|ru}} 2014. Novosibirsk * [http://skr2.ru/lysenko/lysenko-iz-nedr-zemli.php/ Vladimir Lysenko. From the Earth Bowels to the Stratosphere] {{Link language|ru}} 2014. Novosibirsk * Vladimir Lysenko's travellings. {{Link language|ru}} 2016. Volgograd * Vladimir Lysenko. Photosketches of 100 most interesting and various countries. {{Link language|ru}} 2017. Novosibirsk ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Vladimir Lysenko}} * [http://skr2.ru/ Union of Russian Around-the-World Travellers site] {{link language|ru}} * [http://gkrkr.ru/ Himalayan Club of Russian Rafters & Kayakers site] {{link language|ru}} * [http://8000rivers.web-online.ru/ Down-the-Highest-World-Peaks Rafters & Kayakers Clubs] *[http://lib.ru/TURIZM/lisenko1.txt Рафтинг в Гималаях (Rafting in Himalayas)] {{link language|ru}} by Vladimir Lysenko *[http://www.kulichki.com/moshkow/TURIZM/LYSENKO/ Lib.Ru: Владимир Лысенко] {{link language|ru}} Books by Vladimir Lysenko *[http://www.trud.ru/article/06-09-2003/61637_po_marshrutu_zolotoj_lixoradki.html ПО МАРШРУТУ "ЗОЛОТОЙ ЛИХОРАДКИ" (Route "Gold Rush")] ''Труд'' (165), 2003-09-06. {{link language|ru}} *[http://www.veslo.ru/2001/othet/vershina/koksu.html ЛОЦИЯ реки КОКСУ из ОТЧЕТа (Pilot River Cox's Report)] {{link language|ru}} *[http://www.trud.ru/issue/article.php?id=200112082280603 ГОСТЕПРИИМСТВО ЛЮДОЕДОВ (Hospitality Ogre)] {{link language|ru}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lysenko, Vladimir}} [[Category:Travelers]] [[Category:Circumnavigators of the globe]] [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kharkiv]]

{{Other uses|WEO (disambiguation)}} The annual '''''World Energy Outlook''''' is the [[International Energy Agency]]'s flagship publication, widely recognised as the most authoritative source for global [[energy]] projections and analysis. It represents the leading source for medium to long-term [[energy market]] projections, extensive [[statistics]], [[analysis]] and advice for both [[government]]s and the [[Energy industry|energy business]]. It is produced by the Office of the Chief Economist, presently under the direction of Dr. [[Fatih Birol]].
Using a Reference [[Scenario analysis|Scenario]] based on no change in current policies, it enables [[policy-makers]] to evaluate their current path. The WEO has also developed an alternative [[Scenario analysis|scenario]] that puts the global energy systems on a trajectory to stabilise [[greenhouse gas emissions]] in line with limiting the increase in temperature to 2°C.
==World Energy Outlook 2005 to 2011==
In even-numbered years, WEO presents detailed [[Forecasting|projections]] of [[energy demand]], [[Manufacturing|production]], [[trade]] and [[investment]], fuel by fuel and region by region. The report also regularly puts a spotlight on topical issues:
The 2005 [http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/2005.asp] edition presents a detailed assessment of energy prospects throughout the Middle East and North Africa region and the implications of these for world [[energy market]]s; The 2007 [http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/2007.asp] report presents a special focus on China and India and analyses the impact of rising [[energy]] use in these countries on the international energy markets and energy-related [[greenhouse gas emissions]]; The 2008 [http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/2008.asp] edition focuses on two pressing issues such as prospects for [[oil]] and [[gas]] production and the post-2012 [[Climate change mitigation scenarios|climate scenarios]]; The 2009 [http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/2009.asp] edition presents in-depth analysis of three special topics: Financing [[energy development|energy investment]] under a post-2012 climate framework; prospects for global [[natural gas]] markets and energy trends in [[Southeast Asia]].
The 2010 WEO edition, released on 9 November 2010, presented for the first time in its history a scenario that takes account of the recent commitments that [[government]]s have made to tackle [[climate change]] and worsening [[energy security|energy insecurity]]. It also puts the spotlight on several topical issues, including the outlook for [[renewable energy]] [[Technology|technologies]] and [[unconventional oil]], the implications of climate policies, [[Caspian Sea|Caspian]] energy prospects, energy poverty and energy subsidies.<ref name=industcards> {{cite web |url = http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/docs/weo2010/weo2010_london_nov9.pdf |title = World Energy Outlook 2010 |publisher = [[International Energy Agency]] |date = 2010-11-09 |format = PDF |accessdate = 2010-12-03 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101121135236/http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/docs/weo2010/weo2010_london_nov9.pdf |archivedate = 2010-11-21 |df = }} </ref>
The [http://www.iea.org/weo/%20executive%20summary%20reported 2011 report] was issued on 9 November 2011. The executive summary noted that there were "few signs that the urgently needed change in direction in global energy trends is underway." [http://fds.duke.edu/db/Nicholas/esp/faculty/rgn3 Richard G. Newell], associate professor of energy and [[environmental economics]] at Duke University notes: "Even as mature economies moderate oil demand through efficiency and biofuels, emerging economies' oil demand for transport grows by almost 50 percent. The bottom line is, like it or not, we should be prepared for price swings at the pump for some time to come."<ref>http://today.duke.edu/2011/11/tipworldenergy</ref>
==World Energy Outlook 2012== Fatih Birol, Chief Economist of the International Energy Agency (IEA) designed and directed the study which was prepared by the IEA's Directorate of Global Energy Economics of the International Energy Agency and other offices of the Agency. <ref name=weo2012>{{cite report|url=http://www.sc-eco.univ-nantes.fr/~tvallee/memoire/salazar/World%20Energy%20Outlook%202012.pdf|format=PDF|title=World Energy Outlook 2012|publisher=[[International Energy Agency]]|ISBN=978-92-64-18084-0|date=|location=Paris, France}}</ref>
===Global energy trends=== Based on the New Policies Scenario, the central model used by the [[OECD]]'s [[International Energy Agency]], in Part A entitled ''Global energy demands'', on the emerging global energy landscape, over the period to 2035, global energy demand would increase by more one-third with China, India and the Middle East accounting for 60 percent of that increase.<ref name=weo2012/>
===Focus on energy efficiency=== Part B <ref name=weo2012/>
===Iraq energy outloook=== In Part C of the study
The WEO received numerous awards [http://www.iea.org/publications/worldenergyoutlook/aboutweo/awards/] from [[government]]s and [[energy industry]] for its analytical excellence.
